case_name: Sunder Lal Son v. Bharat Handicrafts Private Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 32 of 1965 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 32 of 1965. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 13, 1963 of the Calcutta High Court in Award Case No. 119 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 13, 1963 of the Calcutta High Court in Award Case No. 119 of 1963. Sachin Chowdhury, M. G. Poddar and D. N. Mukherjee, for the appellant.

facts.text: Appellants Messrs Sunder Lal Son are members of the East India Jute and Hessian Exchange Ltd., an Association recognised under the Forward Contracts Regulation Act, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Messrs Sunder Lal Son--hereinafter called the appellants--are members of the East India Jute and Hessian Exchange Ltd. an Association recognised under the provisions of the Forward Contracts  Regulation  Act, 1952.

facts.text: Appellants applied to the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta under s. 33 of the Indian Arbitration Act 1940 for an order declaring valid arbitration agreement contained in contract No. 750 dated September 16, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The- appellants applied to the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta on its original side under s. 33 of the Indian Arbitration Act 10 of 1940 for an order, inter alia, declaring that there exists a valid arbitration agreement companytained in companytract No. 750 dated September 16, 1960 between the petitioners and the respondents.

facts.text: Appellants claimed they entered into a contract with respondents on September 16, 1960, for purchase of 6,00,000 bags of B Twill at Rs. 132.50 nP per 100 bags, on own account in Transferable Specific Delivery Form.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants claimed that they entered into a companytract with the respondents on September 16, 1960, for the purchase of 6,00,000 bags of B Twill at the rate of Rs. 132.50 nP per 100 bags, on their own account in Transferable Specific Delivery Form prescribed under the byelaws of the Association.

facts.text: Respondents denied the existence of the contract and its validity.

anchor.surface_text: and on terms and companyditions set out therein The respondents denied the existence of the companytract and also its validity.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court dismissed the application holding the contract invalid as it did not comply with s. 15 sub-s. 4 of the Forward Contracts Regulation Act, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court dismissed the application holding that M J N 6SCI-13 the companytract was invalid in that it did number companyply with the requirements of s. 15 sub-s.  4  of the Forward Contracts  Regulation  Act, 1952.

facts.text: Validity of contract challenged by respondents on two grounds: 1. appellants were not members of the Association at relevant time; 2. requirements of s. 15(4) of Forward Contracts Regulation Act not complied with.

anchor.surface_text: Validity of the companytract was challenged by the respondents on, two grounds- 1  that the appellants were number at the relevant time members of the Association and  2  that the requirements of s.  4  of the Forward Contracts  Regulation Act were number companyplies with

facts.text: Appellants averred in their petition that they were at all material times members of the Association.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants averred in their petition that they were at all material times members of the Association.

facts.text: Baburam Saraf, principal officer of the Company, in affidavit in reply merely stated he did not admit appellants' membership averment.

anchor.surface_text: Baburam Saraf principal officer of the. Company-in his affidavit in reply merely states that he did number admit that averment.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court held unable to find that appellants proved they were members at time of contract formation.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge observed that he was unable to hold that the appellants had proved that the appellants were members of the Association at the time of the formation of the companytract.

facts.text: Respondents filed plaint in City Civil Court, Calcutta, for declaration that there was no contract No. 750 dated September 16, 1960 between them and appellants.

anchor.surface_text: admission made by the respondents in paragraph 6 of the plaint filed by them in the City Civil Court, Calcutta, for a declaration that there was in fact numbercontract between them and the appellants bearing No. 750 dated September 16, 1960

facts.text: In para 6 of their City Civil Court plaint, respondents averred that appellants were members of East India Jute Hessian Exchange Ltd at all material times.

anchor.surface_text: in which the respondents had averred that they had discovered that the appellants at all material times were the members of the said East India Jute Hessian Exchange Ltd.

facts.text: Counsel for respondents did not seek to support High Court decision on first ground (non-membership).

anchor.surface_text: In view of this evidence, companynsel for the respondents did number seek to support the decision of the High Court on the first ground, and numberhing more need be said in that behalf.

facts.text: Central Government issued notification declaring s.15(1) of Forward Contracts Regulation Act applicable to forward contracts in jute and jute goods.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that the Central Government has issued a numberification declaring s. 15 1  of the Act as applicable to forward companytracts in jute and jute goods.

facts.text: Respondents are not members of the association.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants entered into the companytract with the respondents-who are number members of the association-

facts.text: Bought and sold notes constitute the contract between parties, dated September 16, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant recitals in the numberes, which, it was claimed, companystituted the companytract between the parties may first be set out 7A, Clive Row, Calcutta-1 Sunder Lal Son. Contract No. 750 Messrs. Bharat Handicrafts  Private  Ltd. Dear Sirs, We have, subject to the terms and companyditions hereinafter referred to, this day sold to Messers., Sunderlal Son by Your order, and on your account Yours faithfully, Sunderlal Sons.

facts.text: Confirmation slip was detached from sold note and not produced before High Court by appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The companyfirmation slip was it appears detached from the sold numbere, but it was number produced before the High Court by the appellants.

facts.text: Appellants sought to tender confirmation slip signed by M.L. Bahati in Supreme Court, but Supreme Court declined additional evidence.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellants says that the respondents did give a slip companyfirming the companytract in the sold numbere, but it was unfortunately number tendered in evidence in the High Court, and he applies for leave to tender in evidence that companyfirmation slip in this Court. The companyfirmation slip sought to be produced in this Court purports to bear the companyfirmation by a person who has signed it as M.L. Bahati.

facts.text: Supreme Court held contract did not comply with s.15(4) requirements as no writing evidencing consent or authority of respondents, hence invalid.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore bold that the High Court was right in holding that the companytract did number companyply with the requirements of sub-s.  4  of s. 15 and was on that account invalid.

facts.text: Appeal dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal therefore fails and is dismissed with companyts.

holdings.text: The appellants were members of the East India Jute and Hessian Exchange Ltd. at all material times.

anchor.surface_text: admission made by the respondents in paragraph 6 of the plaint filed by them in the City Civil Court, Calcutta, for a declaration that there was in fact no contract between them and the appellants bearing No. 750 dated September 16, 1960, in which the respondents had averred that they had discovered that the appellants at all material times were the members of the said East India Jute Hessian Exchange Ltd. In view of this evidence, counsel for the respondents did not seek to support the decision of the High Court on the first ground, and nothing more need be said in that behalf.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Respondents' admission in their City Civil Court plaint constitutes evidence; their counsel conceded and did not support High Court's contrary finding.

holdings.text: Additional evidence of the confirmation slip is not allowed.

anchor.surface_text: This document was admittedly in the possession of the appellants and could have been produced by them in the High Court. No rational explanation is furnished for not producing the document before the High Court. Again the document does not prove itself... We therefore decline to allow this additional evidence to be brought on the record.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Document was in appellants' possession but not tendered in High Court without explanation; no substantial cause under O.41 R.27 CPC; does not prove authority without further evidence of signature and authorization.

holdings.text: There is no writing evidencing the consent or authority of the respondents to the appellants entering into a contract on their own account.

anchor.surface_text: There is accordingly no writing evidencing the consent or authority of the appellants entering into a contract on their own account with the respondents in respect of jute goods, and it is not the case of the appellants that they had secured written confirmation of such consent or authority by the respondents within three days from the date of the contract.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bought and sold notes do not disclose authority; confirmation slip detached, not produced, and unsigned by authorized person; appellants' signature on sold note does not evidence respondents' consent.

holdings.text: Sub-section (4) of section 15 renders a forward contract invalid if entered without writing evidencing or confirming the non-member's consent or authority.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellants, however, contends that sub-s. 4 of s. 15 does not invalidate a contract merely because there is no writing evidencing or confirming the consent or authority of the non-member... In our judgment that view cannot be accepted as correct. The Legislature has by the Act imposed diverse restrictions... So long as there is no writing as is contemplated by s. 15(4) or the proviso thereto, there is no enforceable contract.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prohibition under s.15(4) lifted only by disclosure and writing/confirmation; condition for enforceable contract; public interest against malpractices; rejects directory interpretation and prior High Court view in Bajrang Jute Mills; harmonious with ss.15(1),(2).

holdings.text: The High Court was right in holding that the contract did not comply with the requirements of sub-s. (4) of s. 15 and was on that account invalid.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore hold that the High Court was right in holding that the contract did not comply with the requirements of sub-s. 4 of s. 15 and was on that account invalid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms High Court on s.15(4) non-compliance due to absence of required writing.

holdings.text: Section 20(2) penalizes entry into forward contract without disclosing that it is on own account, not failure to secure consent or authority.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 20 sub-s. 2 of the Act a penalty is imposed on any person who enters into a forward contract in contravention of the provisions contained in sub-s. 4 of s. 15... A reasonable reading of that clause is that a person who enters into a contract without disclosing that he contracts on his own account is liable to be punished. It could obviously not have been intended by the Parliament to punish a person for failing to secure the consent or authority of the other party to the contract.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading limits penalty to non-disclosure; consent depends on other party's volition; penal provision does not restrict s.15(4) prohibition.

holdings.text: The appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal therefore fails and is dismissed with costs.

precedents.citation: Shri Bajrang Jute Mills Ltd. v. Lalchand Dugar 1, 68 Cal. W.N. 749

anchor.surface_text: Reliance is placed in support of that plea upon Shri Bajrang Jute Mills Ltd. v. Lalchand Dugar 1 , in which the Calcutta High Court observed in dealing with the validity of a companytract entered into by a member of a recognised association on his own account with a number-member in respect of specified goods We think that the first proviso to section 15 4  is directory in the sense that the securing of the written companyfirmation

precedents.case_name: Shri Bajrang Jute Mills Ltd v Lalchand Dugar
precedents.cited_proposition: The first proviso to section 15(4) is directory and failure to secure written confirmation of consent or authority does not invalidate the forward contract or render it illegal or void
precedents.cited_holding: We think that the first proviso to section 15 4 is directory in the sense that the securing of the written confirmation of the contract is no more than a condition subsequent as to which the responsible members may be blamable or punishable if he does not secure it, but his failure to do so does not invalidate the contract. We think that on a true construction of section 15 4 the failure of the member to obtain the written confirmation of the oral consent or authority to enter into the forward contract on his own account does not render the contract either illegal or void.

justification_sets.label: Order 41 Rule 27, Code of Civil Procedure support

anchor.surface_text: The appeal therefore fails and is dismissed with companyts.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed upholding High Court finding that the contract was invalid for non-compliance with requirements of s. 15 sub-s. (4) of the Forward Contracts Regulation Act, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: admission made by the respondents in paragraph 6 of the plaint filed by them in the City Civil Court, Calcutta, for a declaration that there was in fact no contract between them and the appellants bearing No. 750 dated September 16, 1960, in which the respondents had averred that they had discovered that the appellants at all material times were the members of the said East India Jute Hessian Exchange Ltd. In view of this evidence, counsel for the respondents did not seek to support the decision of the High Court on the first ground, and nothing more need be said in that behalf.
The appeal therefore fails and is dismissed with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: This document was admittedly in the possession of the appellants and could have been produced by them in the High Court. We therefore decline to allow this additional evidence to be brought on the record.
The appeal therefore fails and is dismissed with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: There is accordingly no writing evidencing the consent or authority of the appellants entering into a contract on their own account with the respondents in respect of jute goods, and it is not the case of the appellants that they had secured written confirmation of such consent or authority by the respondents within three days from the date of the contract.
The appeal therefore fails and is dismissed with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellants, however, contends that sub-s. 4 of s. 15 does not invalidate a contract merely because there is no writing evidencing or confirming the consent or authority of the non-member... In our judgment that view cannot be accepted as correct. The Legislature has by the Act imposed diverse restrictions... So long as there is no writing as is contemplated by s. 15(4) or the proviso thereto, there is no enforceable contract.
The appeal therefore fails and is dismissed with companyts.
